subject: Fwd: [junit] JUnitScenario 0.1 released
msgSnippet: Hello, For me, there are quite lots of differences... first of all, it s easiest :) Just write a small XML file and u can already simulate the users using ur
messageBody:
Hello,

For me, there are quite lots of differences... first of all, it's
easiest :) Just write a small XML file and u can already simulate the
users using ur applications...
This was my initial goal, I spend 2 minutes writing this file, no
compilation, i just type "junitscenario" and i can see if my
applications have the required scability.

The difference is also in the long time goal. We will sooon develop a
plugin to easily drag and drop ur functionnal tests to create the
scenario file.
And then, save data like memory consumation and excution time to
create nice reports ( and detect long methods or memory leak)

Hope it's more clear !

On Wed, 23 Feb 2005 10:07:04 -0500, Jason Rogers
<jacaetevha@...> wrote:
>
> Stéphane TRAUMAT wrote:
>
> >
> > Hi
> >
> > We just released a new product under LGPL.. maybe it could interest you..
> >
> > Description: JunitScenario is an automation framework on top of JUnit
> > to perform functional tests and stressing tests.
> > JUnitScenario is a tool to simulate real life usage of applications.
> > It allows you to describe scenarios that are composed of unit tests
> > calls and simulate several users following those scenarios.
> >
> > For example, this scenario.xml file defines the cashier scenario:
> >
> > <scenario name="cashier" users="20" loops="500">
> > <task JUnitClass="org.mybank.MyFirstTest"
> > JUnitMethod="testCreateAccount" wait="10"/>
> > <task JUnitClass="org.mybank.MyFirstTest"
> > JUnitMethod="testDipositMoney" wait="10"/>
> > <task JUnitClass="org.mybank.MyFirstTest"
> > JUnitMethod="testWithdrawMoney" wait="50"/>
> > </scenario>
> >
> > The goal is to have a very easy way to use your unit tests to test
> > your application scability.
> >
> > This document describes how to setup the example:
> > http://junitscenario.sourceforge.net/?action=example
> >
> > Visit JUnitScenario homepage at http://junitscenario.sourceforge.net/
> >
> > This release is just a first shot; we are planning to refactor it,
> > develop an eclipse plug-in to easily build scenarios, store tests in a
> > database for statistics.
> >
> > --
> > Stéphane TRAUMAT
> > scub.net
> > +33 (0)6 18 39 77 25
>
> Not meaning to sound rude, but how does this significantly differ from
> JUnitPerf? It sounds very much the same to me.
>
> --
> Jason Rogers
